{{redirect|Abortion rights|the UK advocacy organization|Abortion Rights (organisation)|the Irish advocacy organisation|Abortion Rights Campaign}} [[File:Pro choice feminists in Sao Paulo.jpg|thumb|300px|Abortion-rights activists in [[São Paulo, Brazil]].]] '''Abortion-rights movements''', also referred to as '''pro-choice movements''', advocate for [[abortion law|legal]] access to induced [[abortion]] services. The issue of induced abortion remains divisive in public life, with [[abortion debate|recurring arguments]] to liberalize or to restrict access to legal abortion services. Abortion-rights supporters themselves are frequently divided as to the types of abortion services that should be available and to the circumstances, for example different periods in the pregnancy such as [[Late termination of pregnancy|late term abortions]], in which access may be restricted.
==Terminology== {{Refimprove|section|date=November 2017}} Many of the terms used in the debate are [[Framing (social sciences)|political framing]] terms used to validate one's own stance while invalidating the opposition's. For example, the labels "pro-choice" and "pro-life" imply endorsement of widely held values such as [[liberty]] and [[Freedom (political)|freedom]], while suggesting that the opposition must be "anti-choice" or "anti-life" (alternatively "pro-coercion" or "pro-death").<ref>{{cite book |title=Handbook of Constructionist Research |author=Holstein |author2=Gubrium |last-author-amp=yes |publisher= Guilford Press |year=2008 |isbn=}}</ref> These views do not always fall along a binary; in one [[Public Religion Research Institute]] poll, seven in ten Americans described themselves as "pro-choice", while almost two-thirds described themselves as "pro-life".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://publicreligion.org/research/2011/06/committed-to-availability-conflicted-about-morality-what-the-millennial-generation-tells-us-about-the-future-of-the-abortion-debate-and-the-culture-wars/ |publisher=Public Religion Research Institute |title=Committed to Availability, Conflicted about Morality: What the Millennial Generation Tells Us about the Future of the Abortion Debate and the Culture Wars |date=June 9, 2011}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] favors the terms "abortion rights" and "anti-abortion" instead.<ref>Goldstein, Norm, ed. The Associated Press Stylebook. Philadelphia: Basic Books, 2007.</ref>
==Early history== Feminists of the late 19th century were often opposed to the legalization of abortion.<ref>Gordon, Sarah Barringer. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Kg4PAtekGoAC&pg=PA67&dq=#PPA67,M1 "Law and Everyday Death: Infanticide and the Backlash against Woman's Rights after the Civil War."] ''Lives of the Law''. Austin Sarat, Lawrence Douglas, and Martha Umphrey, Editors. (University of Michigan Press 2006) p.67</ref><ref name="Schiff">{{cite newspaper|first=Stacy|last=Schiff|author-link=Stacy Schiff|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/13/opinion/13schiff.html?_r=2&oref=slogin&pagewanted=print|title=Desperately Seeking Susan.|date=13 October 2006|newspaper=New York Times|access-date=5 February 2009}}</ref> In [[The Revolution (newspaper)|''The Revolution'']], operated by [[Elizabeth Cady Stanton]] and [[Susan B. Anthony]], an anonymous contributor signing "A" wrote in 1869 about the subject, arguing that instead of merely attempting to pass a law against abortion, the root cause must also be addressed.
Simply passing an anti-abortion law would, the writer stated, "be only mowing off the top of the noxious weed, while the root remains. [...] No matter what the motive, love of ease, or a desire to save from suffering the unborn innocent, the woman is awfully guilty who commits the deed. It will burden her conscience in life, it will burden her soul in death; But oh! thrice guilty is he who drove her to the desperation which impelled her to the crime."<ref name="Schiff" /><ref name=prolifequakers>{{cite web| title=Marriage and Maternity | url=http://www.prolifequakers.org/susanb.htm | work=[[The Revolution (newspaper)|''The Revolution'']] | publisher=[[Susan B. Anthony]] | date=July 8, 1869 | accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref><ref>Susan B. Anthony, [http://honors.syr.edu/Courses/03-04/wsp200/july81869.html “Marriage and Maternity,”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005033006/http://honors.syr.edu/Courses/03-04/wsp200/july81869.html |date=2011-10-05 }} ''[[The Revolution (newspaper)|The Revolution]]'' (1869-07-08), via University Honors Program, Syracuse University.</ref><ref>Federer, William. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8GebI40OvYAC&pg=PA81&dq=%22woman+is+awfully+guilty+who+commits+the+deed%22 American Minute]'', page 81 (Amerisearch 2003).</ref>
===Britain=== [[File:Stella Browne.gif|thumb|right|[[Stella Browne]] was a pioneering feminist who campaigned for the liberalization of abortion law.]] The movement towards the liberalization of abortion law emerged in the 1920s and '30s in the context of the victories that had been recently won in the area of [[birth control]]. Campaigners including [[Marie Stopes]] in England and [[Margaret Sanger]] in the US had succeeded in bringing the issue into the open, and birth control clinics were established which offered family planning advice and contraceptive methods to women in need.
In 1929, the [[Infant Life (Preservation) Act 1929|Infant Life Preservation Act]] was passed in Britain, which amended the law ([[Offences against the Person Act 1861]]) so that an abortion carried out in good faith, for the sole purpose of preserving the life of the mother, would not be an offence.<ref>[[Hansard|HL Deb]]. Vol 72. [http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1928/nov/22/preservation-of-infant-life-bill-hl|Col 269].</ref>
[[Stella Browne]] was a leading birth control campaigner, who increasingly began to venture into the more contentious issue of abortion in the 1930s. Browne's beliefs were heavily influenced by the work of [[Havelock Ellis]], [[Edward Carpenter]] and other [[sexologists]].<ref name="Hall">{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Lesley|title=The Life and Times of Stella Browne: Feminist and Free Spirit|year=2011|pages=27–178}}</ref> She came to strongly believe that working women should have the choice to become pregnant and to terminate their pregnancy while they worked in the horrible circumstances surrounding a pregnant woman who was still required to do hard labour during her pregnancy.<ref>Jones, Greta. "Women and eugenics in Britain: The case of Mary Scharlieb, Elizabeth Sloan Chesser, and Stella Browne." ''[[Annals of Science]]'' 52 no. 5 (1995):481-502</ref> In this case she argued that doctors should give free information about birth control to women that wanted to know about it. This would give women agency over their own circumstances and allow them to decide whether they wanted to be mothers or not.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rowbotham|first=Sheila|title=A New World for Women: Stella Browne, social feminist|year=1977|pages=66–67}}</ref>
In the late 1920s Browne began a speaking tour around England, providing information about her beliefs on the need for accessibility of information about birth control for women, women’s health problems, problems related to puberty and sex education and high maternal morbidity rates among other topics.<ref name="Hall"/> These talks urged women to take matters of their sexuality and their health into their own hands. She became increasingly interested in her view of the woman’s right to terminate their pregnancies, and in 1929 she brought forward her lecture “The Right to Abortion” in front of the [[World Sexual Reform Congress]] in London.<ref name="Hall"/> In 1931 Browne began to develop her argument for women’s right to decide to have an [[abortion]].<ref name="Hall"/> She again began touring, giving lectures on abortion and the negative consequences that followed if women were unable to terminate pregnancies of their own choosing such as: suicide, injury, permanent invalidism, madness and blood-poisoning.<ref name="Hall"/>
[[File:Aleck bourne trial.jpg|thumb|left|[[Aleck Bourne]] was acquitted for performing an abortion on a rape victim in 1938, a landmark case in the movement for abortion rights.]] Other prominent feminists, including [[Frida Laski]], [[Dora Russell]], [[Joan Malleson]] and [[Janet Chance]] began to champion this cause - the cause broke dramatically into the mainstream in July 1932 when the [[British Medical Association]] council formed a committee to discuss making changes to the laws on abortion.<ref name="Hall"/> On 17 February 1936, [[Janet Chance]], Alice Jenkins and [[Joan Malleson]] established the [[Abortion Law Reform Association]] as the first [[advocacy]] organisation for abortion liberalization. The association promoted access to [[abortion in the United Kingdom]] and campaigned for the elimination of legal obstacles.<ref name="HindellSimms">{{cite journal|last=Hindell|first=Keith|author2=Madeline Simms|title=How the Abortion Lobby Worked|year=1968|journal=[[The Political Quarterly]]|pages=271–272}}</ref> In its first year ALRA recruited 35 members, and by 1939 had almost 400 members.<ref name="HindellSimms"/>
The ALRA was very active between 1936 and 1939 sending speakers around the country to talk about Labour and Equal Citizenship and attempted, though most often unsuccessfully, to have letters and articles published in newspapers. They became the most popular when a member of the ALRA’s Medico-Legal Committee received the case of a fourteen-year-old girl who had been raped, and received a termination of this pregnancy from Dr. [[Joan Malleson]], a progenitor of the ALRA.<ref name="HindellSimms"/> This case gained a lot of publicity, however once the war began, the case was tucked away and the cause again lost its importance to the public.
In 1938, [[Joan Malleson]] precipitated one of the most influential cases in British abortion law when she referred a pregnant fourteen-year old [[rape]] victim to [[gynaecology|gynaecologist]] [[Aleck Bourne]]. He performed an abortion, then illegal, and was put on trial on charges of procuring abortion. Bourne was eventually acquitted in ''Rex v. Bourne'' as his actions were "...an example of disinterested conduct in consonance with the highest traditions of the profession".<ref>R v Bourne [1939] 1 KB 687, [1938] 3 All ER 615, [[Court of Criminal Appeal|CCA]]</ref> This court case set a precedent that doctors could not be prosecuted for performing an abortion in cases where pregnancy would probably cause "mental and physical wreck".
The [[Abortion Law Reform Association]] continued its campaigning after the War, and this, combined with broad social changes brought the issue of abortion back into the political arena in the 1960s. President of the [[Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists]] [[John Peel (gynaecologist)|John Peel]] chaired the committee advising the [[British Government]] on what became the [[1967 Abortion Act]], which allowed for legal abortion on a number of grounds, including to avoid injury to the physical or mental health of the woman or her existing child(ren) if the pregnancy was still under 28 weeks.<ref name="Commons 1967">House of Commons, Science and Technology Committee. "Scientific Developments Relating to the Abortion Act 1967." 1 (2006-2007). Print.</ref>
===United States=== {{main article|United States abortion-rights movement}} {{see also|Abortion in the United States}}
[[File:USSC justice group photo-1973 current.jpg|thumb|right|350px|The [[United States Supreme Court]] membership in 1973 at the time of ''[[Roe v. Wade]]''.]] In America an abortion reform movement emerged in the 1960s. In 1964 [[Gerri Santoro]] of Connecticut died trying to obtain an illegal abortion and her photo became the symbol of the pro-choice movement. Some women's rights activist groups developed their own skills to provide abortions to women who could not obtain them elsewhere. As an example, in Chicago, a group known as "[[Jane Collective|Jane]]" operated a floating abortion clinic throughout much of the 1960s. Women seeking the procedure would call a designated number and be given instructions on how to find "Jane".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cwluherstory.org/something-real-jane-and-me-memories-and-exhortations-of-a-feminist-ex-abortionist.html|title=Something Real: Jane and Me. Memories and Exhortations of a Feminist Ex-Abortionist|last=Johnson|first=Linnea|publisher=CWLU Herstory Project|accessdate=2010-05-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725214230/http://www.cwluherstory.org/something-real-jane-and-me-memories-and-exhortations-of-a-feminist-ex-abortionist.html|archive-date=2011-07-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In the late 1960s, a number of organizations were formed to mobilize opinion both against and for the legalization of abortion. The forerunner of the [[NARAL Pro-Choice America]] was formed in 1969 to oppose restrictions on abortion and expand access to abortion.<ref>[http://www.nwhn.org/content/index.php?pid=106 National Women's Health Network | A Voice For Women, A Network For Change<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In late 1973 NARAL became the National Abortion Rights Action League.
The landmark judicial ruling of the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] in ''[[Roe v. Wade]]'' ruled that a [[Texas]] statute forbidding abortion except when necessary to save the life of the mother was unconstitutional. The Court arrived at its decision by concluding that the issue of abortion and abortion rights falls under the [[Privacy laws of the United States|right to privacy]]. The Court held that a right to privacy existed and included the right to have an abortion. The court found that a mother had a right to abortion until viability, a point to be determined by the abortion doctor. After viability a woman can obtain an abortion for health reasons, which the Court defined broadly to include psychological well-being in the decision [[Doe v. Bolton]], delivered concurrently.
From the 1970s, and the spread of [[second-wave feminism]], abortion and [[reproductive rights]] became unifying issues among various [[feminism|women's rights]] groups in Canada, the United States, the Netherlands, Britain, Norway, France, Germany, and Italy.<ref>LeGates, Marlene. ''In Their Time: A History of Feminism in Western Society'' Routledge, 2001 {{ISBN|0-415-93098-7}} p. 363-364</ref>
==Around the world== {{AbortionLawsMap|size=350px}}
===Africa=== {{See also|Abortion in Namibia|Abortion in South Africa|Abortion in Zimbabwe}} [[Abortion in South Africa|South Africa]] allows abortion on demand under its [[Choice on Termination of Pregnancy Act]]. Most African nations, however, have abortion bans except in cases where the woman's life or health is at risk. A number of abortion-rights international organizations have made altering abortion laws and expanding [[family planning]] services in [[sub-Saharan Africa]] and the [[developing world]] a top priority.
===Argentina=== {{See also|Abortion in Argentina}} Because Argentina is very restrictive against abortion, reliable reporting on abortion rates is unavailable. Argentina is a [[Religion in Argentina|strongly Catholic country]], and protesters seeking liberalized abortion in 2013 directed anger toward the Catholic Church.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Infobae.com Society Reporting staff|title=In San Juan, pro-abortion militants burned an image of the Pope (En San Juan, militantes pro aborto quemaron una imagen del Papa)|url=http://www.infobae.com/2013/11/26/1526476-en-san-juan-militantes-pro-aborto-quemaron-una-imagen-del-papa/|accessdate=31 July 2017|work=infobae.com|date=26 Nov 2013|language=Spanish|quote=Frente a la catedral, un grupo de católicos que hizo una muralla humana para evitar la profanación del templo debió soportar insultos, escupitajos y manchas de pintura.}}</ref> Argentina is the home of the anti-violence organization [[Ni una menos]], which was formed in 2015 to protest the murder of Daiana García, which opposes the violation of a woman's right to choose the number and interval of pregnancies.<ref name="surcapitalino">{{cite web |url=http://www.surcapitalino.com.ar/detalle_noticias.php?Id=3598|title=Maratón de lectura contra los femicidios |language=Spanish|date=March 26, 2015|publisher=Sur Capitalino|access-date=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://niunamenos.com.ar/?page_id=16|website=niunamenos.com.ar|accessdate=31 July 2017|title=Ley de protección integral para prevenir, sancionar y erradicar la violencia contra las mujeres.}}</ref>
===Ireland=== {{main article|Abortion in the Republic of Ireland|Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018}}
==== Republic of Ireland ==== Abortion is illegal in the [[Republic of Ireland]] except when the woman's life is threatened by a medical condition (including risk of suicide), since [[Eighth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|a 1983 referendum (aka 8th Amendment)]] amended the [[Constitution of Ireland|constitution]]. Subsequent [[Amendments to the Constitution of Ireland|amendments]] in 1992 (after the [[X Case]]) – the [[Thirteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|thirteenth]] and [[Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|fourteenth]] – guaranteed the right to travel abroad (for abortions) and to distribute and obtain information of "lawful services" available in other countries. Two proposal to remove suicide risk as a ground for abortion were rejected by the people, [[Twelfth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 1992|in a referendum in 1992]] and [[Twenty-fifth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland Bill 2002|in 2002]]. Thousands of women get around the ban by privately travelling to the other European countries (typically Britain and the Netherlands) to undergo termination,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6639673.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=Irish teen wins abortion battle|date=9 May 2007}}</ref> or by ordering [[Medical abortion|abortion pills]] from [[Women on Web]] online and taking them in Ireland.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Irish Times|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/environment/fall-in-seizures-of-drugs-that-induce-abortion-1.1407015|title=Fall in seizures of drugs that induce abortion|date=27 May 2013|first=Fiona|last=Gartland}}</ref>
The [[Sinn Féin]], [[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour Party]], [[Social Democrats (Ireland)|Social Democrats]], [[Green Party (Ireland)|Green Party]], [[Communist Party of Ireland|Communist Party]], [[Socialist Party (Ireland)|Socialist Party]] and [[Irish Republican Socialist Party]] have made their official policies to support abortion rights. Mainstream centre-right parties such as [[Fianna Fáil]] and [[Fine Gael]] do not have official policies on abortion rights but allow [[conscience vote]] on supportive of abortion in limited circumstances <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/sinn-fein-abortion-referendum-3845129-Feb2018/|title='I trust women': Sinn Féin says it will be 'knocking on doors' to repeal the Eighth Amendment|last=Finn|first=Christina|work=TheJournal.ie|access-date=2018-03-24|language=en}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/fianna-fail-eighth-amendment-repeal-3810499-Jan2018/|title='Households will be split' - Leading Fianna Fáil TD doesn't back his leader on abortion|last=Duffy|first=Rónán|work=TheJournal.ie|access-date=2018-03-24|language=en}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/majority-fine-gael-view-on-abortion-referendum-expected-1.3355364|title=Majority Fine Gael view on abortion referendum expected|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2018-03-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
After the [[death of Savita Halappanavar]] in 2012, there has been a renewed campaign to [[Eighth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland#Repeal the Eighth|repeal the eighth amendment]] and legalize abortion. {{Asof|2017|1}}, the Irish government has set up a [[Citizens' Assembly (Ireland)|citizens assembly]] to look at the issue. Their proposals, broadly supported by a cross-party Oireachtas committee, include repeal of the 8th Amendment, unrestricted access to abortion for the first 12 weeks of pregnancy and no-term limits for special cases of fatal foetal abnormalities, rape and incest. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.citizensassembly.ie/en/The-Eighth-Amendment-of-the-Constitution/Final-Report-on-the-Eighth-Amendment-of-the-Constitution/|title=Final Report on the Eighth Amendment of the Constitution - The Citizens' Assembly|website=www.citizensassembly.ie|language=en|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://beta.oireachtas.ie/en/committees/32/eighth-amendment-constitution/|title=Committee on the Eighth Amendment of the Constitution|date=2018-01-24|website=beta.oireachtas.ie|language=en-ie|others=Houses of the Oireachtas|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref>
A referendum on the repealing of the 8th Amendment was held on 25 May 2018. [[Together for Yes]] a cross-society group formed from the Coalition to Repeal the 8th Amendment, [[National Women's Council of Ireland]] and the [[Abortion Rights Campaign]] will be the official campaign group for repeal in the referendum. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.togetherforyes.ie/about-us/who-we-are/|title=Who We Are - Together For Yes|work=Together For Yes|access-date=2018-03-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
==== Northern Ireland ==== {{see also|Abortion in Northern Ireland}} Despite being part of the [[United kingdom]], abortion is also illegal in Northern Ireland, except in cases when the woman is threatened by a medical condition, physical or mental.<ref>''Rex v Bourne'' [1939] 1 KB 687, [1938] 3 All ER 615, [[Court of Criminal Appeal|CCA]]</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Q&A: Abortion in Northern Ireland|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/1386450.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=December 9, 2011|date=June 13, 2001}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{main article|Abortion in the United Kingdom}} In the United Kingdom, the [[Abortion Act 1967]] legalized abortion on a wide number of grounds, except in [[Northern Ireland]]. In Great Britain, the law states that pregnancy may be terminated up to 24 weeks <ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7412118.stm | work=BBC News | title=MPs reject cut in abortion limit | date=2008-05-21 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> if it:
#puts the life of the pregnant woman at risk #poses a risk to the mental and physical health of the pregnant woman #poses a risk to the mental and physical health of the fetus #shows there is evidence of extreme fetal abnormality i.e. the child would be seriously physically or mentally handicapped after birth and during life.<ref>{{UK-LEG|title=Abortion Act 1967|type=ukpga|path=/ukpga/1967/87}}.</ref>
However, the criterion of risk to mental and physical health is applied broadly, and ''de facto'' makes abortion available on demand,<ref>[http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2002/297.html R v British Broadcasting Corporation, ex parte ProLife Alliance] [2002] EWCA Civ 297 at [6], [2002] 2 All ER 756 at 761, CA</ref> though this still requires the consent of two [[National Health Service]] doctors. Abortions in Great Britain are provided at no out-of-pocket cost to the patient by the NHS.
The [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] are predominantly pro-abortion-rights parties, though with significant minorities in each either holding more restrictive definitions of the right to choose, or subscribing to an anti-abortion analysis. The [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] is more evenly split between both camps and its former leader, [[David Cameron]], supports abortion on demand in the early stages of pregnancy.<ref>[http://archive.catholicherald.co.uk/article/20th-june-2008/3/david-cameron-supports-abortion-on-demand David Cameron supports abortion on demand], [[Catholic Herald]], 20 June 2008.</ref>
===Iran=== {{main article|Abortion in Iran}} Abortion was first legalized in 1978.<ref>[[Eliz Sanasarian]], ''The Women's Rights Movements in Iran'', Praeger, New York: 1982, {{ISBN|0-03-059632-7}}.</ref> In April 2005, the [[Majlis of Iran|Iranian Parliament]] approved a new bill easing the conditions by also allowing abortion in certain cases when the fetus shows signs of handicap,<ref name=BBC_2005-04-12>{{cite news|publisher=BBC|last=Harrison|first=Frances|date=12 April 2005|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4436445.stm|title=Iran liberalises laws on abortion|access-date=12 May 2006}}</ref><ref name=LifeSiteNews_2005-05-09>"{{cite web|url=http://www.lifesite.net/ldn/2005/may/05050909.html|title=Iran Rejects Easing of Abortion Law]|date=9 May 2005|publisher=LifeSiteNews.com|accessdate=12 May 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=10&categ_id=2&article_id=14225|title=Iran's Parliament eases abortion law|date=13 April 2005|newspaper=The Daily Star|access-date=12 May 2006}}</ref> and the [[Council of Guardians]] accepted the bill in 15 June 2005.<ref name=LifeSiteNews_2005-05-09/> Legal abortion is now allowed if the mother's life is in danger, and also in cases of fetal abnormalities that makes it not viable after birth (such as anencephaly) or produce difficulties for mother to take care of it after birth, such as major [[thalassemia]] or bilateral polycystic kidney disease.
===United States=== {{Main article|Abortion in the United States}} Abortion-rights advocacy in the United States is centered in the [[United States pro-choice movement]].
===Japan=== {{main article|Abortion in Japan}} Chapter XXIX of the [[Penal Code of Japan]] makes [[abortion]] illegal in Japan. However, the [[:ja:母体保護法|Maternal Health Protection Law]] allows [[:ja:母体保護法指定医師|approved doctors]] to practice abortion with the consent of the mother and her spouse, if the pregnancy has [[Pregnancy from rape|resulted from rape]], or if the continuation of the pregnancy may severely endanger the maternal health because of physical reasons or economic reasons. Other people, including the mother herself, trying to abort the [[fetus]] can be punished by the law. People trying to practice abortion without the consent of the woman can also be punished, including the doctors.
===Poland=== {{Main|Abortion in Poland}} Poland initially held abortion to be legal in 1958 by the communist government, but was later banned after restoration of democracy in 1989.
Currently, abortion is illegal in all cases except for rape or when the fetus or mother is in fatal conditions.<ref>Douglas, C. A. (1981, Nov 30). Poland restricts abortion. ''Off our Backs, 11'', 14. Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/197142942</ref> The wide spread of [[Catholic Church in Poland]] within the country has made abortion socially 'unacceptable'<ref>Douglas, C. A. (1994, 03). Poland: Feminists vs. the church. ''Off our Backs, 24'', 10. Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/197123721</ref> <sup>.</sup> [[Pope|The Pope]] has had major influence on the acceptance of abortion within Poland<ref>Kalbarczyk, P. (2013). Abortion in poland: The change that never happened.''Conscience, 34''(1), 38-39. Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/1411117675</ref> <sup>.</sup> Several landmark court cases have had substantial influence on the current status of abortion, including [[Tysiąc v Poland|Tysiac v Poland]].<ref>Hewson, B. (2007). Abortion in poland: A new human rights ruling. ''Conscience, 28''(2), 34-35. Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/195070632</ref> Women have slowly lost several reproductive rights while gaining democratic rights.<ref>Grzywacz, A. (2016). Poland's paradox - loss of sexual and reproductive rights in a democratic poland. ''Conscience, 37''(1), 55-58. Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/1816620435</ref> Consequently, several protests have recently happened. Most recently, several women took to the street to protest the abortion ban on Black Monday.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-37540139|title=Black Monday: Polish women strike against abortion ban|last=|first=|date=October 3, 2016|website=|publisher=BBC|access-date=}}</ref> Black Monday was not successful in changing the ban on abortion, however it raised awareness.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/24/polish-abortion-law-protesters-march-against-proposed-restrictions|title=Polish abortion law protesters march against proposed restrictions|last=Press|first=Associated|date=2016-10-24|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref>

{{Abortion}}
[[Category:Sexual revolution]] [[Category:Pro-choice movement| ]] [[Category:Abortion]]

'''Abu Ubaidah al-Banshiri''' ({{lang-ar|أبو عبيدة البنشيري}}; May 1950 – May 21, 1996) was the ''[[nom de guerre]]''<ref name="idc">[http://meria.idc.ac.il/journal/2004/issue2/jv8n2a6.html Tactical Deception and Strategic Surprise in al-Qai’da’s Operations] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070213062341/http://meria.idc.ac.il/journal/2004/issue2/jv8n2a6.html |date=February 13, 2007 }}, [[Richard H. Shultz]] and Ruth Margolies Beitler; (other sources agree on his real name)</ref> of '''Ali Amin al-Rashidi''' (علي أمين الرشيدي), one of the "most capable and popular leaders"<ref>[[9/11 Commission]], "Final Report", p. 65</ref> of [[al-Qaeda]].<ref name="ARNAOUT">[http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/iln/indict/2002/02cr892.pdf Indictment of Enaam Arnaout] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630065050/http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/iln/indict/2002/02cr892.pdf |date=2007-06-30 }} in 2002, archive at the US Department of Justice; describes the founding of al-Qaeda</ref><ref name="gsecfounding">[http://www.globalsecurity.org/security/profiles/al-qaeda_gains_first_members.htm Al-Qaeda gains first members], GlobalSecurity.org</ref><ref name="gsecAU">[http://www.globalsecurity.org/security/profiles/abu_ubaidah_al-banshiri.htm Abu Ubaidah al-Banshiri], GlobalSecurity.org</ref>
When he drowned in a ferry accident on [[Lake Victoria]] in 1996, he was the head of al-Qaeda's African presence and second in command of the whole organization, below [[Osama bin Laden]].
==History== {{rquote|right|It is as if 100 years were added to my life when I came to Afghanistan|Abu Ubaidah al-Banshiri<ref>Mansfield, Laura. "His Own Words", p. 27</ref>}} Al-Banshiri was born in May 1950 in [[Cairo]], and served as a policeman in [[Egypt]] before joining the anti-Soviet effort in [[Afghanistan]],<ref name="gsecAU"/> fighting alongside [[Ahmed Shah Massoud]].<ref>Burke, Jason. "al-Qaeda, the true story of radical Islam", p. 106</ref>
His brother had participated in the [[Assassination of Anwar El Sadat|assassination of Egyptian President Anwar El Sadat]]. [[Ayman al-Zawahiri]], head of [[Egyptian Islamic Jihad]], introduced al-Banshiri to [[Osama Bin Laden]], who was so favorably impressed that he made al-Banshiri military commander of the [[Afghan Arabs]]. Al-Bashiri's second in command was [[Mohammed Atef]].<ref>[[Lawrence Wright]], ''The Looming Tower: Al-Qaeda and the Road to 9/11'', Vintage, 2006, {{ISBN|978-1-4000-3084-2}}, p. 147</ref> He was shot in the leg during the 1987 [[Battle of Jaji]].<ref name="berg">[[Peter Bergen|Bergen, Peter]], "The Osama bin Laden I Know', 2006.</ref>
While still in Afghanistan, in August 1988, he attended the founding meeting of al-Qaeda, along with bin Laden, [[Mamdouh Mahmud Salim]], and others.<ref name="founders">[http://www.globalsecurity.org/security/profiles/founders_meet_and_form_al-qaeda.htm Global Security database] on the founding of al-Qaeda</ref>
While in Kenya and Tanzania he was known by the aliases Adel Habib, Karim, and Jalal.<ref name="idc"/> He married a Kenyan woman and set up a business in [[Nairobi]] importing automobiles from the [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref name="sacredcows">Benjamin, Daniel & Steven Simon. "The Age of Sacred Terror", 2002. pp. 130</ref>
At some point al-Banshiri acquired either [[Netherlands|Dutch]] citizenship<ref name="gsecAU"/> or forged Dutch papers.<ref name="idc"/> Prior to 1996, al-Bashiri, [[Mohammed Atef]] and Yaseen al-Iraqi aided [[Enaam Arnaout]] in purchasing [[AK-47]]s and mortar rounds from a Pashtun tribesman named Hajjji Ayoub, and they were subsequently delivered in large trucks to the Jawr and [[Jihad Wahl training camp]]s.<ref name="arnie">Fitzgerald, Patrick J. United States of America v. Enaam M. Arnaout, "[http://news.findlaw.com/wsj/docs/bif/usarnaout10603prof.pdf Governments Evidentiary Proffer Supporting the Admissibility of Co-Conspirator Statements]", before Hon. Suzanne B. Conlon</ref>
==Death== When the news broke that the ferry {{MV|Bukoba}} had sunk in Lake Victoria, al-Qaeda sent [[Fazul Abdullah Mohammed]] and [[Wadih el-Hage]] to the scene, to verify that al-Banshiri had drowned, and had not been murdered.<ref name="day6">[http://www.911investigations.net/IMG/pdf/doc-1337.pdf Transcript of testimony] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070510123223/http://www.911investigations.net/IMG/pdf/doc-1337.pdf |date=2007-05-10 }} in the trial of El Hage and others</ref>
Al-Banshiri was succeeded as al-Qaeda's "military" commander by another Egyptian ex-policeman, [[Mohammed Atef]], who had been considered his inseparable friend. Al-Banshiri's senior role in East Africa was taken over, at least in part, by [[Abdullah Ahmed Abdullah]].<ref name="idc"/>
A poem entitled "Tears in the Eyes of Time" was written about al-Banshiri, commemorating him among the greatest of the "fallen mujahideen". al-Zawahiri recited the poem in his January 2006 internet broadcast.<ref>Atwan, Abdel Bari. "The Secret History of al-Qaeda", p. 225</ref>

{{Infobox royalty|monarch | name =Alan IV | image =Sceau Alain Fregent.jpg | image_size =180px | caption =Alan IV's seal | succession =[[List of rulers of Brittany|Duke of Brittany]] | reign =1072/84–1112 | predecessor =[[Hoel II, Duke of Brittany|Hoel II]] & [[Hawise, Duchess of Brittany|Hawise]] | regent =[[Hoel II, Duke of Brittany|Hoel II]] | successor =[[Conan III, Duke of Brittany|Conan III]] | spouse =[[Constance of Normandy]]
[[Ermengarde of Anjou (d. 1146)|Ermengarde of Anjou]] | issue =[[Conan III, Duke of Brittany]]
Geoffrey
Hawise, Countess of Flanders | house =[[House of Cornouaille|Cornouaille]] | father =[[Hoel II, Duke of Brittany]] | mother =[[Hawise, Duchess of Brittany]] | birth_date =before 1060 or 1063x1066 | birth_place = | death_date =13 October 1119 | death_place =[[Redon Abbey]] | place of burial=[[Redon Abbey]] | religion =[[Roman Catholicism]] | signature = }} '''Alan IV''' (born circa 1063; died 13 October 1119) was [[Duke of Brittany]] from 1084 until his abdication in 1112. He was also [[Count of Nantes]] (from c. 1103) and [[Count of Rennes]]. His parents were [[Hawise, Duchess of Brittany|Duchess Hawise]] and [[Hoel II, Duke of Brittany|Duke Hoel II]]. He is also known as '''Alan Fergant'''. Through his father, he was of the Breton House of Cornouaille dynasty ([[Breton language|Breton]]: ''Kerne'' dynasty). He was the last [[Breton language|Breton-speaking]] Duke of Brittany.Gwenno Piette, ''A concise History of Brittany'' (University of Wales Press, Cardiff, 2008), p. 36 ==Norman Conflict== A traditional rivalry between [[Duchy of Brittany|Brittany]] and [[Duchy of Normandy|Normandy]] continued at the close of the 11th century. The Breton-Norman war of 1064–1065 was the result of [[William I of England|William the Bastard]], Duke of Normandy (later to become known as William the Conqueror) support of rebels in Brittany against Alan's maternal uncle, [[Conan II, Duke of Brittany|Conan II]]. Conan II died in late 1066 during a campaign in Anjou, and was succeeded by Alan's parents, Conan's sister Hawise and her husband Hoel II. Hoel ruled as regent from Hawise's death in 1072 until Alan reached his majority in 1084.{{sfn|Following medieval examples given in Bailey et al., Alan may have been twenty-one years of age at that time}} To prevent further hostilities during his invasion of England, William I married his daughter [[Constance of Normandy|Constance]] to the new duke Alan in 1087.J. A. Everard, ''Brittany and the Angevins: Province and Empire 1158–1203'', (Cambridge University Press, 2004), 10. The marriage ceremonies may have taken place in [[Bayeux]] in Normandy. [[William of Malmesbury]] wrote that Constance was unpopular at the Breton court because of her "severe and conservative" manner. However, [[Orderic Vitalis]] wrote that as duchess Constance did all she could to further the welfare of the Bretons, who grieved deeply at her death in 1090. In 1092 Alan IV donated property to the [[Redon Abbey|abbey of Redon]] by charter, and by 1093 married [[Ermengarde of Anjou (d. 1146)|Ermengarde of Anjou]], as a political alliance with [[Fulk IV of Anjou]] to counter Anglo-Norman influence. [[File:Redon - Abbatiale Saint-Sauveur et Mairie - Cylindrique - 20090704.jpg|thumb|left|Redon Abbey, Final resting place of Alan IV]] Duke Alan IV's cousin Geoffrey I Boterel (eldest brother of Alan Rufus) died on 24 August 1093 in battle at Dol while in rebellion against the Duke. Between 1101 and 1104, Alan's younger brother, Count [[Matthew II of Nantes]], died without issue and his county passed to Alan. Alan IV abdicated as duke in 1112. The former duke retired to the monastery of Redon, where he died in 1119. ==Crusader== In 1098 Alan went on the [[First Crusade]],J. A. Everard, ''Brittany and the Angevins: Province and Empire 1158–1203'', 12. as part of the [[Army of Robert Curthose on the First Crusade|army of Robert Curthose]], leaving Ermengarde as his regent, and returned in 1101. ==Family== Alan IV married [[Constance of Normandy|Constance]] in 1087. Constance died in 1090. They had no children. Alan's second marriage was to [[Ermengarde of Anjou (d. 1146)|Ermengarde of Anjou]] in 1093. With Ermengarde he had three children: *Geoffrey - died young; * [[Conan III, Duke of Brittany|Conan]] - his successor as Duke of Brittany * Hawise - she married Count [[Baldwin VII of Flanders]], also known as ''Hawise Fergant.'' They divorced and had no issue. Alan and Ermengarde were separated upon his abdication as duke in 1112. He had two illegitimate sons, [[Brian Fitzcount]]W. L. Warren, ''Henry II'', (University of California Press, 1974), 74. and Guihomar.Orderic Vital, Auguste Le Prevost [https://books.google.fr/books?id=zn9WAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA248&dq=Guiumar+Brito+filius+Alanni+comitis&hl=fr&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiE4dji3aLXAhVoDcAKHSTBB7cQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=Guiumar%20Brito%20filius%20Alanni%20comitis&f=false Historiae ecclesiasticae], Libris tredecim, Tomus IV, pp 428-429. ==Succession== Alan IV died in 1119 at the monastery of Redon, where he had retired after his abdication in 1112, and separation from his wife Ermengarde. His only surviving son, [[Conan III, Duke of Brittany|Conan III]] succeeded him. ==See also== *[[Dukes of Brittany family tree]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== *{{cite news|title=Coming of Age and the Family in Medieval England |DOI=10.1177/03631990073084492008 |journal=Journal of Family History |volume=33 |number=1 |date=January 2008 |pages=41–60 |author=B. Gregory Bailey |author2=Meaghan E. Bernard |author3=Gregory Carrier |author4=Cherise L. Elliott |author5=John Langdon |author6=Natalie Leishman |author7=Michal Mlynarz |author8=Oksana Mykhed |author9=Lindsay C. Sidders |last-author-amp=yes}} ==External links== {{commons category|Alain IV de Bretagne}} *http://patp.us/genealogy/conq/richmond.aspx {{s-start}} {{S-hou|House of Cornouaille|||13 October|1119}} {{s-reg}} {{s-bef|before=[[Hoel II, Duke of Brittany|Hoel II]] }} {{s-ttl|title=[[Duke of Brittany]]|years=1084–1112}} {{s-aft|rows=3|after=[[Conan III, Duke of Brittany|Conan III]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Geoffrey Grenonat|Geoffrey I]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Count of Rennes]]|years=1084–1112}} {{s-bef|before=[[Matthew II of Nantes|Matthew II]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Count of Nantes]]|years=1103–1112}} {{end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Alan IV, Duke Of Brittany}} [[Category:1119 deaths|Brittany, Alan IV, Duke of]] [[Category:Dukes of Brittany]] [[Category:Christians of the First Crusade]] [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]]

{{Infobox spacecraft class | name = Biosatellite | image = [[File:Biosat3.jpg|150px]] | image_caption = Biosatellite 3 | manufacturer = [[General Electric]] | designer = | country = [[United States]] | operator = [[NASA]] | applications = Bioscience | design_life = 8-30 days | launch_mass = | dry_mass = | payload_capacity = | dimensions = | volume = | power = | batteries = | equipment = | orbits = [[Low Earth orbit]] | status = Retired | built = | launched = 3 | retired = | failed = | lost = | first = [[Biosatellite 1]]
15 February 1967 | last = [[Biosatellite 3]]
29 June 1969 | lastretired = | derivedfrom = | derivatives = | bottom_image = | bottom_image_caption = }} [[NASA]] launched three satellites named '''Biosatellite 1, 2 and 3''' between 1966 and 1969. NASA's Biosatellite program was a series of three satellites to assess the effects of spaceflight, especially radiation and weightlessness, on living organisms. Each was designed to reenter and be recovered at the end of its mission. Its primary goal was that it intended to determine effects of space environment, particularly weightlessness, on life processes at three levels of organization: basic biochemistry of the cell; structure of growth of cells and tissues; and growth and form of entire plants and animals.{{cite web|last=Rosenthal|first=Alfred|title=A record of NASA space missions since 1958|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2060/19940003358|work=NASA|publisher=NASA Technical Reports Server|accessdate=24 September 2011}} ==Biosatellite 1== The Biosatellite 1, also known as abbreviated '''Biosat 1''' and as '''Biosatellite A''', was a first artificial satellite unmanned U.S. belonging to Biosatellite program for biological research. It was released on December 14, 1966 by a rocket [[Delta (rocket)|Delta G]] from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17A]] of the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]].[http://astronautix.com/craft/biollite.htm Biosatellite]. Encyclopedia Astronautica. Retrieved 2016-16-05. The Biosatellite 1 was the first series Biosatellite satellites. It was released in an initial orbit of 296 km perigee 309 km apogee and 33.5 degrees of orbital inclination, with period 90.5 minutes. The Biosatellite 1 was carrying several specimens for the study of the effects of the space environment on biological processes. The capsule was returning to land separated from the vehicle properly, but its rocket did not work, leaving it stranded in a slowly decaying orbit. It re-entered and disintegrated on February 15, 1967. ==Biosatellite 2== The Biosatellite 2, also known as abbreviated as '''Biosat 2''' and as '''Biosatellite B''', was a second artificial satellite unmanned U.S. belonging to Biosatellite program for biological research. It was released on September 7, 1967 by a rocket Delta G Launch Complex 17B of the Air Force from [[Cape Canaveral]] station.[http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/biosat.htm Biosat 1, 2, 3 (Bios 1, 2, 3)]. Gunter's Space Page. Retrieved 2016-16-05. The Biosatellite 2 carried thirteen biological experiments involving insects, frog eggs, plants and microorganisms. The capsule returned early due to a tropical storm threat.[http://www.astronautix.com/b/biosatellite.html Biosatellite 2]. Mark Wade, ''Astronautix''. Accessed 14 June 2018. ==Biosatellite 3== The Biosatellite 3, also known as abbreviated '''Biosat 3''' and as '''Biosatellite D''', was a third artificial satellite unmanned U.S. belonging to Biosatellite program for biological research. Despite the seeming failure of the mission's scientific agenda, Biosatellite 3 was influential in shaping the life sciences flight experiment program, pointing to the need for centralised management, realistic goals and substantial pre-flight experiment verification testing. The mission objective was to investigate the effect of space flight on [[brain]] states, behavioural performance, cardiovascular status, fluid and [[electrolyte]] balance, and metabolic state.{{cite web|url=https://lsda.jsc.nasa.gov/scripts/mission/miss.aspx?mis_index=56|title=Mission information: Biosatellite III|work=[[NASA]]|accessdate=25 May 2016}} {{PD-notice}} Biological capsule reentered in 7 September 1969. ==Table== {|border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |-bgcolor="#f7f7f7" !Satellite !Rocket !Launch date !Launch site !Decay date ![[COSPAR ID]] ![[Satellite Catalog Number|SATCAT]] |- |[[Biosatellite 1]] |[[Delta (rocket family)|Delta G]] |14 December 1966 |[[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 17|LC-17B]] |15 February 1967 |1966-114A |02632 |- |[[Biosatellite 2]] |[[Delta (rocket family)|Delta G]] |7 September 1967 |[[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 17|LC-17B]] |4 October 1967 |1967-083B |09236 |- |[[Biosatellite 3]] |[[Delta (rocket family)|Delta N]] |29 June 1969 |[[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 17|LC-17A]] |7 July 1969 |1969-056A |04000 |} ==Gallery== Biosat1.jpg|Biosatellite 1 Biosatellite II.png|Drawing of Biosatellite 2 Biosatelliet3.png|Location of the [[monkey]] on the Biosatellite 3 ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[Bion (satellite)|Bion space program]] * [[BIOPAN]] * [[Biosatellite]] * [[EXPOSE]] * [[List of microorganisms tested in outer space]] * [[O/OREOS]] * [[OREOcube]] *[[Tanpopo (mission)|Tanpopo]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120501115530/http://lis.arc.nasa.gov/lis/ Life into Space: 1965-1990] {{Astrobiology}} {{portal bar|Astrobiology}} {{Use American English|date=January 2014}} [[Category:NASA satellites]] [[Category:NASA programs]] [[Category:Astrobiology space missions]] [[Category:Space-flown life]] [[Category:Animals in space]] [[Category:Biosatellites]]

revision.text:
{{update|date=November 2010}} [[File:Brawling, 喧嘩, PA160113aaa.jpg|thumb|280px|right|The [[yakuza]]'s fight by festival of Japan]]
'''Brawling''' (probably connected with German language ''brüllen'', to roar, shout), in law, was the offence of quarrelling, or creating a disturbance in a [[church (building)|church]] or churchyard. Brawling was covered in [[Ecclesiastical court|ecclesiastic courts]] until 1860. It has rarely been prosecuted since then.
==History== During the early stages of the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]] in England religious controversy too often became converted into actual disturbance, and the ritual lawlessness of the [[Wikt:parochial|parochial]] [[clergy]] very frequently provoked popular violence. To repress these disturbances the [[Brawling Act 1551]] was passed in 1551, by which it was enacted: "that if any person shall, by words only, quarrel, chide or brawl in any church or churchyard, it shall be lawful for the ordinary of the place where the same shall be done and proved by two lawful witnesses, to suspend any person so offending, if he be a layman, from the entrance of the church, and if he be a clerk, from the ministration of his office, for so long as the said ordinary shall think meet, according to the fault."<ref name="EB1911">{{EB1911|inline=1 |wstitle=Brawling |volume=4 |page=437}}</ref>
An Act of 1553 added the punishment of imprisonment until the party should repent. The Brawling Act 1551 was partly repealed in 1828 and wholly repealed as regards laymen by the [[Ecclesiastical Courts Jurisdiction Act 1860]]. Under that Act, which applies to [[Ireland]] as well as to England, persons guilty of riotous, violent or indecent behaviour, in churches and chapels of the Church of England or Ireland, or in any chapel of any religious denomination, or in England in any place of religious worship duly certified, or in churchyards or burial-grounds, were liable on conviction before two justices to a penalty of not more than £5, or imprisonment for any term not exceeding two months. This enactment applied to clergy as well as to laity, and a clergyman of the Church of England convicted under it could also be dealt with under the [[Clergy Discipline Act 1892]] (''Girt v. Fillingham'', 1901, L.R. Prob. 176).<ref name="EB1911"/>
When Mr [[John Kensit|J. Kensit]] during an ordination service in [[St Paul's Cathedral]] "objected" to one of the candidates for ordination, on grounds which did not constitute an impediment or notable crime within the meaning of the ordination service, he was held to have unlawfully disturbed the [[bishop]] of [[London]] in the conduct of the service, and to be liable to conviction under the Act of 1860 (''Kensit'' v. ''Dean and Chapter of St Paul's'', 1905, L.R. 2 K.B. 249). The public worship of [[Protestant]] Dissenters, [[Roman Catholic]]s and [[Jews]] in England had before 1860 been protected by a series of statutes beginning with the [[Act of Toleration 1689|Toleration Act]] of 1689, and ending with the [[Liberty of Religious Worship Act 1855]]. These enactments, though not repealed, were for practical purposes superseded by the summary remedy given by the Act of 1860. In Scotland disturbance of public worship is punishable as a [[breach of the peace]] (''Dougall'' v. ''Dykes'', 1861, 4 Irvine 101).<ref name="EB1911"/>
===In the British Empire=== In British possessions abroad, interference with religious worship was usually dealt with by legislation, and not as a common-law offence. In [[India]] it was an offence voluntarily to cause disturbance to any assembly lawfully engaged in the performance of religious worship or religious ceremonies (Penal Code, s. 296). Under the [[Queensland Criminal Code]] of 1899 (s. 207) penalties were imposed on persons who wilfully and without lawful justification or excuse (the proof of which lies on them) disquiet or disturb any meeting of persons lawfully assembled for religious worship, or assault any forces lawfully officiating at such meeting, or any of the persons there assembled.<ref name="EB1911"/>
===In the United States=== In the United States disturbance of religious worship is treated as an offence under the [[common law]], which is in many states supplemented by legislation (see Bishop, ''Amer. Crim. Law,'' 8th ed. 1892, vol. i. s. 542, vol. ii. ss. 303-305; California Penal Code, s. 302; ''Revised Laws of Massachusetts'', 1902, chap. 212, s. 30.).<ref name="EB1911"/> -- (Dissenting correction to the above)
==Modern case== In 1998, [[Peter Tatchell]] of [[OutRage!]] was prosecuted for interrupting the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]]'s Easter sermon with a short gay rights speech.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.petertatchell.net/religion/easter%20sunday.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090924202506/http://www.petertatchell.net/religion/easter%20sunday.htm |archivedate=2009-09-24 |df= }}</ref> The 1860 legislation (which transferred jurisdiction away from the ecclesiastic courts) was used to try him; his defense focused on the [[Human Rights Act 1998]]. He was convicted and fined £18.60 (referring to the 1860 legislation) plus court costs.
==See also== *The [[Brawling Act 1553]]

Olsen Energy]]) | Ship operator = Dolphin Drilling | Ship registry = {{unbulleted list | {{SIN}} | {{PAN}} (1974–2005)}} | Ship route = | Ship ordered = | Ship builder = [[Aker Group]] | Ship original cost = | Ship yard number = Aker Verdal A/S (695) | Ship way number = | Ship laid down = 31 October 1972 | Ship launched = | Ship completed = 1 February 1974 | Ship christened = | Ship acquired = | Ship maiden voyage = | Ship in service = | Ship out of service = | Ship identification = {{unbulleted list | [[Call sign]]: 9VDG7 | [[Det Norske Veritas|DNV ID:]] 09092 | {{IMO Number|8750584}} | [[Maritime Mobile Service Identity|MMSI no.:]] 563601000}} | Ship fate = | Ship status = Operational | Ship notes = <ref name=dnv1/><ref name=fredolsen/> }} {{Infobox ship characteristics | Hide header = | Header caption = | Ship class = [[Det Norske Veritas|DNV class]]: 1A1 Column-stabilised Drilling Unit UKVS | Ship tonnage = {{unbulleted list | {{GT|11,792}} | {{GT|3,538}} }} | Ship displacement = | Ship length = {{convert|108.2|m|abbr=on}} | Ship beam = {{convert|67.4|m|abbr=on}} | Ship draught = | Ship depth = {{convert|36.6|m|abbr=on}} | Ship decks = | Ship deck clearance = | Ship ramps = | Ship ice class = | Ship sail plan = | Ship power = | Ship propulsion = | Ship speed = 4.5 kn | Ship capacity = {{unbulleted list | Variable Deck Load: 3,021 [[Tonne|t]] | Liquid Mud: 3,981 bbls (534 m<sup>3</sup>) | Bulk Mud/Cement: 547 t / 270 t}} | Ship crew = 102 berths | Ship notes = <ref name=dnv1/><ref name=fredolsen>{{cite web | title=Byford Dolphin | url=http://www.fredolsen-energy.no/?aid=9048931 | publisher=Fred.Olsen Energy ASA | date=24 February 2008 | accessdate=14 July 2010}}</ref> }} |}
'''''Byford Dolphin''''' is a [[Semi-submersible platform|semi-submersible]], column-stabilised [[offshore drilling|drilling rig]] operated by Dolphin Drilling, a [[Fred. Olsen Energy]] subsidiary, and in 2009 contracted by [[BP]] for drilling in the United Kingdom section of the [[North Sea]] for three years.<ref name=upstream190509>{{cite news | url=http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article178497.ece | title=Byford Dolphin gets Senergy extra-time | work=Upstream | publisher=NHST Media Group | date=2009-05-19 | accessdate=2010-05-23}}</ref><ref name=offshore-mag170210>{{cite news | url=http://www.offshore-mag.com/index/article-display/articles/offshore/drilling-completion/north-sea-northwest-europe-2/2010/02/fred-olsen_upgrading.html | title=Fred Olsen upgrading fleet for drilling upturn | publisher=[[PennWell Corporation]] | work=Offshore Magazine | date=2010-02-17 | accessdate=2010-05-23}}</ref><ref name=offshore181209>{{cite news |work=Offshore.no International |publisher=Offshore Media Group|title=Byford Dolphin-agreement|url=http://www.offshore.no/international/news/article.aspx?id=15588|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130223004859/http://www.offshore.no/international/news/article.aspx?id=15588|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-02-23 |first=Elisabeth|last=Kolstad|date=2009-12-18|accessdate=2012-11-05}}</ref> It is registered in [[Hamilton, Bermuda]].<ref name="dnv1">{{cite ship register |register=DNV |id=09092 |shipname=Byford Dolphin |accessdate=14 July 2010 }}</ref>
The rig has suffered some serious accidents, most notably an [[explosive decompression]] in 1983 that killed four divers and one dive tender, and badly injured another dive tender.<ref name="pmid3381801">{{cite journal |vauthors=Giertsen JC, Sandstad E, Morild I, Bang G, Bjersand AJ, Eidsvik S |title=An explosive decompression accident |journal=American Journal of Forensic Medicine and Pathology |volume=9 |issue=2 |pages=94–101 |date=June 1988 |pmid=3381801 |doi= 10.1097/00000433-198806000-00002|url= |accessdate= }}</ref>
== Description == ''Byford Dolphin'' drilling rig is an Enhanced [[Aker Solutions|Aker]] H-3 design which was built by [[Aker Group]] at the Aker Verdal shipyard in 1974.<ref name=rigzone1>{{Cite web | title=Rig Data: ''Byford Dolphin'' | publisher=Rigzone | url=http://www.rigzone.com/data/rig_detail.asp?rig_id=102 | accessdate =2010-05-23}}</ref> Between 1974 and 1978, it was named '''''Deep Sea Driller'''''.<ref name=dnv1/>
''Byford Dolphin'' has a length of {{convert|108.2|m|ft}}, breadth of {{convert|67.4|m|ft}} and depth of {{convert|36.6|m|ft}}. It has a maximum drilling depth of {{convert|6100|m|ft}}, and it could operate at a water depth of {{convert|460|m|ft|-2}}.<ref name=olsen>{{Cite web|title=Byford Dolphin |publisher=[[Fred. Olsen Energy]] |url=http://www.fredolsen-energy.no/arch/_img/9073113.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720154005/http://www.fredolsen-energy.no/arch/_img/9073113.pdf |archivedate=20 July 2011 }}</ref> As a drilling rig, ''Byford Dolphin'' is equipped with advanced drilling equipment and has to meet strict levels of certification under Norwegian law. ''Byford Dolphin'' is able to maneuver with its own [[engine]]s (to counter [[Stokes drift|drift]] and ocean currents), but for long-distance relocation, it must be moved by specialist [[tugboat]]s.
{| class="wikitable" border="1" |+ ''Byford Dolphin'' specifications |- |Operating deck load |3,025 tonne |- |Crew quarters |102 persons |- |Operating water depth |{{convert|460|m|ft|-2}} maximum |- |[[Derrick (lifting device)|Derrick]] |{{convert|49|m|ft|-1|adj=on}} Shaffer top compensator |- |Mooring system |12 point |- |Blow-out preventer |Hydril {{convert|476|mm|in|abbr=on}}, {{convert|10000|kPa|psi|abbr=on}} |- |Sub Sea Handling System |[[Christmas tree (oil well)|Christmas tree]] |- |Deck cranes |2 × 40 tonnes |}
== Accidents and incidents ==
=== ''Deep Sea Driller'' accident ===
On 1 March 1976, the rig ran aground during transit from a block in the North Sea to [[Bergen]]. All crew were evacuated in the life boats, but six people died when they fell from their life boat.<ref>[https://snl.no/Deep_Sea_Driller-ulykken Deep Sea Driller-ulykken] Store norske leksikon. Retrieved 29 September 2014</ref>
=== Diving bell accident === On 5 November 1983 at 4:00 a.m., while drilling in the [[Frigg gas field]] in the Norwegian sector of the [[North Sea]], four divers were in a [[diving chamber]] system attached by a trunk (a short passage) to a [[diving bell]] on the rig. The divers were Edwin Coward (British, 35 years old), Roy Lucas (British, 38), Bjørn Giæver Bergersen (Norwegian, 29) and Truls Hellevik (Norwegian, 34). They were assisted by two dive tenders, Crammond and Saunders.<ref name="pmid3381801"/>
Hellevik was about to close the door between the chamber system and the trunk when the chamber [[explosive decompression|explosively decompressed]] from a pressure of nine [[Atmosphere (unit)|atmospheres]] to one atmosphere. One of the tenders, 32-year-old William Crammond of Great Britain, and all four of the divers were killed instantly; the other tender, Saunders, was severely injured.<ref name="Limbrick">{{cite book|title=North Sea Divers - a Requiem|last=Limbrick|first=Jim|pages=168–170|location=[[Hertford]]|publisher=Authors OnLine|year=2001|isbn=0 7552 0036 5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lPp68NAoUF0C&pg=PA168}}</ref>
[[File:Byford Dolphin Accident.jpg|thumb|300px|right|The decompression chamber at the moment the accident occurred. D1–D4 are divers; T1 and T2 are dive tenders. The trunk is the section that joins chamber 1 to the diving bell.<ref name="pmid3381801"/>]] The situation just before this accident was as follows: Decompression chambers 1 and 2 were connected via a trunk to a diving bell. This connection was sealed by a clamp operated by two tenders, who were themselves experienced divers. A third chamber was connected to this system but was not involved. On this day, Coward and Lucas were resting in chamber 2 at a pressure of 9 atm. The diving bell with Bergersen and Hellevik had just been winched up after a dive and joined to the trunk. Leaving their wet gear in the trunk, the divers climbed through the trunk into chamber 1.
'''The normal procedure would have been:'''
# Close the bell door. # The diving supervisor would then slightly increase the bell pressure to seal this door tightly. # Close the door between the trunk and chamber 1. # Slowly depressurize the trunk to 1 atmosphere. # Open the clamp to separate the bell from the chamber system.
The first two steps had been completed when, for an unknown reason, one of the tenders (Crammond) opened the clamp before Diver 4 (Hellevik) could close the door to the chamber. This resulted in the explosive decompression of the unsealed chamber. Air rushed out of the chamber with tremendous force, jamming the interior trunk door and pushing the bell away, striking the two tenders. The tender who opened the clamp was killed while the other was severely injured.<ref name="pmid3381801"/><!-- Note for future editors: Hellevik, Diver 4, did not explode as a result of pressure gradient, contrary to popular myth. Please do not edit the text to indicate that he did. The cited text in the Journal of Forensic Medicine and Pathology, although worded poorly, indicates only that the organs were expelled in conjunction with and as a result of being torn in half below the belly button as he passed through the narrow door opening while also being dismembered by the passage. That is the extent of the article's content and assertions. -->
==== Medical findings ==== Medical investigations were carried out on the four divers' remains. The most conspicuous finding of the [[autopsy]] was large amounts of fat in large [[artery|arteries]] and [[vein]]s and in the [[Heart|cardiac chambers]], as well as intravascular fat in organs, especially the [[liver]].<ref name="pmid3381801"/> This fat was unlikely to be [[embolism|embolic]], but must have [[Precipitation (chemistry)|precipitated]] from the blood ''[[in situ]]''. It is suggested the rapid bubble formation in the blood [[Denaturation (biochemistry)|denatured]] the [[lipoprotein]] complexes, rendering the [[lipid]]s insoluble.<ref name="pmid3381801"/> Death of the three divers left intact inside the chambers would have been extremely rapid as circulation was immediately and completely stopped. The fourth diver was dismembered and mutilated by the blast forcing him out through the partially blocked doorway and would have died instantly.<ref name="pmid3381801"/>
Coward, Lucas, and Bergersen were exposed to the effects of [[explosive decompression]] and died in the positions indicated by the diagram. Subsequent investigation by [[forensic pathology|forensic pathologists]] determined that Hellevik, being exposed to the highest pressure gradient and in the process of moving to secure the inner door, was forced through the {{convert|60|cm|in}} [[diameter]] opening created by the jammed interior trunk door by escaping air and violently dismembered, including bisection of his thoracoabdominal cavity, which further resulted in expulsion of all of the internal [[organ (anatomy)|organs]] of his chest and abdomen, except the trachea and a section of small intestine, and of the thoracic [[vertebral column|spine]]. These were projected some distance, one section later being found {{convert|10|m|ft|-1}} vertically above the exterior pressure door.<ref name="pmid3381801" /> ==== Investigation ==== The committee investigating the accident concluded that it was caused by human error on the part of the dive tender who opened the clamp. It is not clear whether the tender who opened the clamp before the trunk was depressurized did so by order of his supervisor, on his own initiative, or because of miscommunication. At the time, the only communication the tenders on the outside of the chamber system had was through a [[bullhorn]] attached to the wall surface; with heavy noise from the rig and sea, it was hard to listen in on what was going on. Fatigue from many hard hours of work also took its toll among the divers, who often worked 16-hour shifts. {{fact|date=June 2018}}
This incident was also attributed to engineering failure. The obsolete ''Byford Dolphin'' diving system, dating from 1975, was not equipped with [[fail-safe]] hatches, outboard pressure gauges, and an interlocking mechanism, which would have prevented the trunk from being opened while the system was under pressure.<ref>Norges offentlige utredninger NOU 1984: 11 Dykkerulykken på Byford Dolphin {{ISBN|82-00-70889-6}}</ref> Prior to the accident, [[Det Norske Veritas|Norske Veritas]] had issued the following rule for certification: "Connecting mechanisms between bell and chambers are to be so arranged that they cannot be operated when the trunk is pressurized,"<ref>'Rules for certification of diving systems Sec 3 B305, 1982'</ref> therefore requiring such systems to have fail-safe seals and interlocking mechanisms. One month after the accident, Norske Veritas and the Norwegian oil directorate made the rule final for all bell systems.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
Among others, former crew members of ''Byford Dolphin'' and NOPEF (a Norwegian oil and petro-chemical union) have come forward and claimed the investigation was a [[cover-up]]. They claimed that the commission investigating the accident did not mention in their report the irresponsible dispensations on vital equipment requested by [[Compagnie maritime d'expertises|Comex]] and authorized by the diving section to the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate, which played a vital role in the accident's occurrence. They also alleged the accident was due to a lack of proper equipment, including clamping mechanisms equipped with interlocking mechanisms (which would be impossible to open while the chamber system was still under pressure), outboard pressure gauges, and a safe communication system, all of which had been held back because of dispensations by the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate.<ref name="dagbladet">{{cite news |url=http://www.dagbladet.no/tekstarkiv/artikkel.php?id=5001080047056&tag=item&words=byford%3Bdolphin |title=Historiens verste dykkerulykke |trans-title=History's worst diving accident |last=Ringheim |first=Gunnar |date=22 March 2008 |publisher=Dagbladet.no |location=Oslo |language=Norwegian |accessdate=2009-11-18}}</ref>
==== Post-investigation ====
The conclusions of the investigation were disputed, and a group of divers gathered evidence with the intention of "find[ing] justice for all of the crew of ''Byford Dolphin''."<ref name="nsda-bd">{{cite web |url=http://www.pioneerdivers.org/index.php?/en/article/byford_dolphin_05111983/ |title=Byford Dolphin Disaster |last=Wingen |first=Tom |work=Pioneer Divers in the Norwegian Sector of the North Sea |publisher=North Sea Divers Alliance |accessdate=2009-10-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727175024/http://www.pioneerdivers.org/index.php?%2Fen%2Farticle%2Fbyford_dolphin_05111983%2F |archivedate=27 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> The group formed the North Sea Divers Alliance in the early 1990s and now{{when|date=January 2018}} campaigns for compensation for divers killed or injured in the Norwegian Sector of the North Sea.<ref name="nsda">{{cite web |url=http://www.pioneerdivers.org/index.php?/en/ |title=Norwegian Sector Divers - Fighting the Norwegian Government over Human Rights Abuses |last=Wingen |first=Tom |work=Pioneer Divers in the Norwegian Sector of the North Sea |publisher=North Sea Divers Alliance |accessdate=2009-10-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100103101013/http://www.pioneerdivers.org/index.php?%2Fen%2F |archivedate=3 January 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==== Subsequent lawsuit ====
The North Sea Divers Alliance, formed by early North Sea divers and the relatives of those killed, continued to press for further investigation and, in February 2008, obtained a report that indicated the real cause was faulty equipment. Clare Lucas, daughter of Roy Lucas, said: "I would go so far as to say that the Norwegian Government murdered my father because they knew that they were diving with an unsafe decompression chamber."<ref>{{cite news |last=Lister |first=David |title=Families of British divers killed in North Sea oil boom sue Norway |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article3613778.ece | work=The Times |accessdate=2009-11-18 | location=London | date=2008-03-25}}</ref> The families of the divers eventually received compensation for the damages from the Norwegian government 26 years after the incident.<ref name=cdiver>{{cite web |author=Staff writers |url=http://cdiver.net/news/norwegian-government-finally-pays-out-for-1983-byford-dolphin-diver-death/#more-3678 |title=Norwegian government finally pays out for 1983 ''Byford Dolphin'' diver death |work=cDiver| date=20 October 2009 | accessdate=14 July 2010}}</ref>
=== Other incidents === On 17 April 2002, a 44-year-old Norwegian worker on the rig was struck on the head and killed in an [[industrial injury|industrial accident]]. The accident resulted in ''Byford Dolphin'' losing an exploration contract with [[Statoil]], which expressed concerns with the rig's operating procedures. The incident cost the company millions of dollars in lost income.<ref name=cdiver/>

'''Cleanliness suitability''' describes the suitability of operating materials and ventilation and air conditioning components for use in cleanrooms where the air cleanliness and other parameters are controlled by way of technical regulations. Tests are carried out to determine this.<ref>VDI 2083, Part 9.1: Cleanroom technology – Compatibility with required cleanliness and surface cleanliness</ref><ref>VDI 2083, Part 17: Cleanroom technology – Cleanroom and cleanliness suitability of materials</ref>
Trends such as the miniaturization of structures as well as increased levels of reliability in technology, research and science require controlled “clean” manufacturing environments. The task of such environments is to minimize influences which could damage the products concerned. The cleanroom environments created by filtering the air were originally developed for the fields of microelectronics and microsystem technology but are now used in a wide range of other high technology sectors such as photovoltaics and the automotive industry.
Depending upon the industry and process concerned, different factors may have a damaging influence on a product, e.g.: # Particles, in microelectronics such as the semiconductor industry and especially biotic particles in life science industries such as pharmaceutics, bio-engineering and medical technology ([[cleanroom suitability]]) # Molecular contamination (outgassing), especially in microelectronics such as the semiconductor industry # Electrostatic discharge phenomena (ESD), especially in microelectronics such as the semiconductor industry # Resistance to cleaning and disinfection agents, especially in life science industries such as pharmaceutics # Surface interaction, especially in life science industries such as pharmaceutics, bio-engineering and medical technology # Cleanability, especially in life science industries such as pharmaceutics, bio-engineering and medical technology # Microbicidity, especially in life science industries such as pharmaceutics, bio-engineering and medical technology
The following factors may be responsible for contamination: # The cleanroom itself: Staff, although this is becoming less relevant as more and more staff are banned from working in critical areas, # The use of manufacturing equipment, which is increasing as more and more automated solutions are being implemented. # Often in direct contact with the product, manufacturing equipment and the materials used in their construction form a further important contamination factor in a clean production environment.
